Text: For the choirmaster: with stringed instruments. A Psalm of David.
Context: This superscription indicates that the Psalm is intended for the choirmaster and is accompanied by stringed instruments, written by David.

Text: Answer me when I call, O God of my righteousness! You have relieved me in my distress; be gracious to me and hear my prayer.
Context: David is appealing to God for a response, acknowledging past relief and seeking further grace and attention to his prayer.

Text: O men, how long will my honor be maligned? How long will you love vanity and seek after lies? Selah
Context: David questions the continued disrespect from others, their pursuit of emptiness and falsehood. The term "Selah" likely signals a pause or musical interlude.

Text: Know that the LORD has set apart the godly for Himself; the LORD will hear when I call to Him.
Context: David expresses confidence that God distinguishes and listens to the righteous.

Text: Be angry, yet do not sin; on your bed, search your heart and be still. Selah
Context: David advises self-reflection and calmness in anger, implicitly referencing a prohibition against sin in anger. "Selah" indicates a break or pause for contemplation.

Text: Offer sacrifices of righteousness and trust in the LORD.
Context: David encourages right actions and a trust in God as acts of worship and devotion.

Text: Many ask, “Who can show us the good?” Lift up the light of Your face upon us, O LORD.
Context: There is a general quest for goodness and David's own longing for God's favor, expressed as the light of God's face.

Text: You have filled my heart with greater joy than when their grain and new wine abound.
Context: David compares the joy in his heart from God's blessings to that experienced during times of material abundance.

Text: I will lie down and sleep in peace, for You alone, O LORD, make me dwell in safety.
Context: David expresses a sense of profound peace and safety as he entrusts himself to God's protection, favoring divine security over physical security.
